results.title: Alan Marshall
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A memorable discussion with an author of extraordinary spirit and charm, who is internationally known for his novel “I Can Jump Puddles”.

results.title: Patterns
results.brief_description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. A number of threads are woven between the sweatshop and the art gallery, the glory box and the political banner, bourgeois femininity and the question: should a feminist knit? An incisive and kaleidoscopic exploration of needlework and its place in women’s lives.

results.title: Changing the needle
results.creator_credit: Martha Ansara, Dasha Ross, Mavis Robertson and Jequerity
results.brief_description: One of the consequences of the Vietnam war is a quarter million Vietnamese drug addicts. This film shot in Vietnam in 1981 shows how an underdeveloped war ravaged country is dealing with this problem. Alternative medicine such as acupuncture, natural medicines and exercises play an important part in the rehabilitation process. It also shows a society trying to cope with material scarcity and poverty - the heritage of underdevelopment and the inevitable result of war. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: A Feeling of self worth
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Vandalism Task Force and Robin Young
results.brief_description: A feeling of self worth describes the approach taken at Monterey and the positive impact this has had on the school. Present and former staff and the parents of former students talk about the school as it used to be and the improvements that have been made.

results.title: News digest [No. 9]
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and ABC
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Kyabram’s rodeo; 12,000 sea shells collected from the world’s beaches; Victoria’s first mobile water patrol equipped with a bar tender cruiser is launched at Sandringham; underwater enthusiasts collect relics from old steamers; movies on the move at the Myer Music Bowl shown by the State Film Centre on a 24 by 8 foot screen as part of the Moomba festivities.

results.title: A Film for Discussion
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Martha Ansara and Sydney Women's Film Group
results.brief_description:
The Sydney Women’s Film Group was formed in 1971 by a small group of feminists who were troubled by the lack of options for women filmmakers in Australia, and appalled by the depiction of women in the media. The group produced and distributed films, held screenings and discussions, ran production workshops for women, and lobbied for women’s access to film funding and education. “Our aim was to further the spread of our revolutionary ideas through the visual media” (Jeni Thornley). Many of Australia’s women filmmakers owe their inspiration or start to this seminal group’s activities.

‘A Film for Discussion’ is the group’s first production, and is possibly the first feminist film made in Australia. The juxtaposition of experimental and realist sequences in the depiction of a ‘day in the life’ of an ordinary young woman, parallels the ‘personal is political’ ethos of 1970s feminism.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film shows a trip to Wilson’s Promontory, Victoria including the beach at Tidal River and a group of people hiking around the prom.

Originally made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:38:00 a banksia tree
00:01:02:00 group of people walking onto a beach with large boulders
00:01:37:00 taking photos on the shoreline
00:02:35:00 woman sketching
00:05:49:00 a little lizard
00:06:27:00 group of people hiking
00:07:43:00 man sitting on a rock looking over a view
00:08:05:00 group of people watching the view
00:09:56:00 the river going into the sea
00:12:23:00 the footbridge at Tidal River
00:14:12:00 a rosella on a branch and feeding from someone’s hand

results.title: Service to the inland (A)
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: A story of the inland telegraph, demonstrating the need for and efficiency of the inland communications system. Shows a message from a Northern Territory bush wireless to Dunlop Tyres translated into a narrative about developments in the outback (transportation, primary industry, the flying doctor etc.). Also includes footage of Aboriginal couriers travelling overland on foot, Aboriginal settlements, their culture, cooking, food gathering etc, in particular Emily’s Gap.

results.title: Festival of the pig
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: Shows the villagers of New Guinea preparing for a feast in which pig is the chief item of food. Their elaborate costumes and a tribal dance are shown, while the sound track includes actual chants.
